revision.text:
[[File:NASA NEXT Ion thruster.712983main NEXT LDT Thrusterhi-res full.jpg|thumb|Image of NASA's Evolutionary Xenon Thruster (NEXT) operation in vacuum chamber]] The '''NASA Evolutionary Xenon Thruster''' ('''NEXT''') project at [[Glenn Research Center]] is an [[ion thruster]] about three times as powerful as the [[NASA Solar Technology Application Readiness|NSTAR]] used on [[Dawn (spacecraft)|Dawn]] and [[Deep Space 1]] spacecraft.<ref name=IAC-08-C442>{{cite web | url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20080047732_2008047267.pdf | title= The NASA Evolutionary Xenon Thruster (NEXT): the next step for US deep space propulsion | author=George R Schmidt | author2=Michael J Patterson | author3= Scott W Benson}}</ref><ref name='2010 Qualification'>{{citation | first = Daniel A. | last = Herman | contribution = NASA’s Evolutionary Xenon Thruster (NEXT) Project Qualification Propellant Throughput Milestone: Performance, Erosion, and Thruster Service Life Prediction After 450 kg | title = 57th Joint Army-Navy-NASA-Air Force (JANNAF) Propulsion Meeting | publisher = NASA - Glenn Research Center | place = Colorado Springs, Colorado, USA | date = May 3–7, 2010| id = | contribution-url = https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20110000521.pdf | accessdate = 2014-03-08}}</ref>
NEXT affords larger delivered payloads, smaller launch vehicle size, and other mission enhancements compared to chemical and other electric propulsion technologies for [[Discovery Program|Discovery]], [[New Frontiers program|New Frontiers]], [[Mars Exploration Program|Mars Exploration]], and [[Flagship Program|Flagship]] outer-planet exploration missions.<ref name='2010 Qualification'/> [[Glenn Research Center]] manufactured the test engine's core ionization chamber, and [[Aerojet Rocketdyne]] designed and built the ion acceleration assembly.<ref name=test/><ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/news/pressrel/2013/13-021_thruster.html NASA Thruster Achieves World-Record 5+Years of Operation]. NASA. June 24, 2013.</ref> The first two flight units will be available in early 2019.
==Performance== The NEXT engine is a type of [[solar electric propulsion]] in which thruster systems use the electricity generated by the spacecraft's [[Solar panel on spacecraft|solar panel]] to accelerate the [[xenon]] propellant to speeds of up to 90,000 mph (145,000 km/h or 40 km/s).<ref name=test/> NEXT can produce 6.9 [[Watt#Kilowatt|kW]] thrust power and 236 [[Newton (unit)|mN]] [[thrust]].<ref name='gizmag2013'>{{cite web| url=http://www.gizmag.com/next-ion-thruster-duration-record/28067/ | title= NASA's NEXT ion thruster runs five and a half years nonstop to set new record | author= David Szondy |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref> It can be throttled down to 0.5 kW power, and has a [[specific impulse]] of 4190 seconds (compared to 3120 for [[NASA Solar Technology Application Readiness|NSTAR]]).<ref name='2010 Qualification'/> The NEXT thruster has demonstrated a total impulse of 17 MN·s; which is the highest total impulse ever demonstrated by an ion thruster.<ref name='2010 Qualification'/> A beam extraction area 1.6 times that of NSTAR allows higher thruster input power while maintaining low voltages and ion current densities, thus maintaining thruster longevity.<ref name='2010 Qualification'/>
==Tests== In November 2010, it was revealed that the prototype had completed a 48,000 hours (5.5 years) test in December 2009.<ref name=test>{{cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2013/jun/HQ_13-193_Ion_Thruster_Record.html | title= NASA Thruster Achieves World-Record 5+ Years of Operation | author=Dwayne Brown | author2=Katherine K. Martin | author3= Glenn Mahone |accessdate=2013-06-24}}</ref><ref name='gizmag2013'/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/next-provides-lasting-propulsion-and-high-speeds-for-deep-space-missions/index.html | title= NEXT Provides Lasting Propulsion and High Speeds for Deep Space Missions | author= Nancy Smith Kilkenny, SGT, Inc. |accessdate=29 September 2013}}</ref> Thruster performance characteristics, measured over the entire throttle range of the thruster, were within predictions and the engine showed little signs of degradation and is ready for mission opportunities.<ref name='2010 Qualification'/>
==Status== NEXT completed its System Requirement Review in July 2015 and Preliminary Design Review in February 2016. The first two flight units will be available in early 2019.<ref name="for sale">{{cite conference |last=Dolloff |first=M. |last2=Jackson |first2=J. |title=Current Status of NASA Evolutionary Xenon Thruster - Commercial (NEXT-C). |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1786.pdf |format=PDF |conference=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference |year=March 2016 }}</ref> The [[CAESAR (spacecraft)|''CAESAR'']] mission concept to comet [[67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko]] is a finalist for the [[New Frontiers program]] mission #4, and if selected in 2019, it will be propelled by the NEXT ion engine.<ref name="SBAG18Squyres">{{cite web |url=https://www.lpi.usra.edu/sbag/meetings/jan2018/presentations/3-15pm-Squyres.pdf |title=CAESAR Project Overview |format=PDF |publisher=[[Lunar and Planetary Institute]] |date=17 January 2018 |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> After that, it will be a commercial product for purchase by NASA and non-NASA customers.<ref name="for sale"/> Aerojet Rocketdyne, and their major sub-contractor ZIN Technologies retain the rights to produce the system, known as '''NEXT-C''' for future commercialization.<ref name="for sale"/>
==See also==
{{Portal| Spaceflight }} *[[Advanced Electric Propulsion System]] *[[Electrically powered spacecraft propulsion]] *[[Hall effect thruster]] *[[Nuclear electric rocket]] *[[Spacecraft propulsion]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Spacecraft propulsion}}
[[Category:Aerospace engineering]] [[Category:Ion engines]]

[[File:Onagawa Nuclear Power Plant.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Onagawa Nuclear Power Plant]], a 3-unit BWR site typical of Japan's nuclear plants.]] [[File:Kashiwazaki Kariwa-April 2011.jpg|thumb| The [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]], a nuclear plant with seven units, the largest single nuclear power station in the world, was completely shut down for 21 months following an earthquake in 2007.<ref name=mycle>[http://www.greens-efa.org/cms/topics/dokbin/206/206749.pdf The European Parliament's Greens-EFA Group - The World Nuclear Industry Status Report 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625044818/http://www.greens-efa.org/cms/topics/dokbin/206/206749.pdf |date=2008-06-25 }} p. 23.</ref>]] [[File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe crop.jpg|thumb|The 2011 [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], the world's worst [[nuclear accident]] since 1986, displaced 50,000 households after [[radioactivity]] leaked into the air, soil and sea.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-26/fukushima-retiree-to-lead-anti-nuclear-motion.html |title=Fukushima Retiree Leads Anti-Nuclear Shareholders at Tepco Annual Meeting |author1=Tomoko Yamazaki |author2=Shunichi Ozasa |lastauthoramp=yes |date=June 27, 2011 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref> Radiation checks led to bans of some shipments of vegetables and fish.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/07/us-japan-nuclear-idUSTRE74610J20110507 |title=Japan anti-nuclear protesters rally after PM call to close plant |author=Mari Saito |date=May 7, 2011 |work=Reuters}}</ref>]]
Prior to the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]], Japan had generated 30% of its electrical power from nuclear reactors and planned to increase that share to 40%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuclear Power in Japan|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf79.html|publisher=World Nuclear Association|accessdate=17 June 2012}}</ref> [[Nuclear power|Nuclear power energy]] was a national strategic priority in Japan. As of May 2018, there are 42 operable reactors in Japan. Of these, 8 reactors in 5 power plants are operating.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuclear Power in Japan {{!}} Japanese Nuclear Energy - World Nuclear Association|url=http://world-nuclear.org/information-library/country-profiles/countries-g-n/japan-nuclear-power.aspx|website=world-nuclear.org|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref><ref name=oi4/>
Though all of Japan's nuclear reactors successfully withstood shaking from the [[Tohoku region|Tohoku]] [[earthquake]], [[Flood|flooding]] from the ensuing [[tsunami]] caused the failure of cooling systems at the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] on 11 March 2011. Japan's first-ever nuclear emergency was declared, and 140,000 residents within {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} of the plant were evacuated. A comprehensive assessment by international experts on the health risks associated with the Fukushima I nuclear power plant disaster concluded in 2013 that, for the general population inside and outside Japan, the predicted risks were low and no observable increases in cancer rates above baseline rates were anticipated.<ref>[http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2013/fukushima_report_20130228/en/ Global report on Fukushima nuclear accident details health risks] [[World Health Organization]], news release 2013-02-28, accessed 2013-07-04</ref> All Japan's nuclear plants were closed, or their operations suspended for safety inspections. The last of Japan's fifty reactors ([[Tomari Nuclear Power Plant#Reactors on site|Tomari-3]]) went offline for maintenance on 5 May 2012,<ref name=Guardian>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/05/japan-shuts-down-last-nuclear-reactor |title=Japan shuts down last working nuclear reactor |author=David Batty |date= May 5, 2012 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> leaving Japan completely without nuclear-produced electrical power for the first time since 1970.
Problems in stabilizing the triple reactor meltdowns at Fukushima I nuclear plant hardened attitudes to nuclear power. In June 2011, more than 80 percent of Japanese said they were [[anti-nuclear]] and distrusted government information on [[radiation]].<ref name=refuse2011>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2011/0620/Beginning-of-the-end-for-nuclear-power-in-Japan |title=Beginning of the end for nuclear power in Japan? |author1=Gavin Blair |date=June 20, 2011 |work=CSMonitor }}</ref><ref name="M. V. Ramana 43">{{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/4/43.abstract |title=Nuclear power and the public |author=M. V. Ramana |date=July 2011 |volume=67 |issue=4 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |page=43 }}</ref><ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2011-09-19/japan-anti-nuclear-protest/50461872/1 |title=Thousands march against nuclear power in Tokyo |date = September 2011|work=USA Today }}</ref> By October 2011, there had been electricity shortages, but Japan survived the summer without the extensive blackouts that some had predicted.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/11/business/energy-environment/after-fukushima-does-nuclear-power-have-a-future.html |title=After Fukushima, Does Nuclear Power Have a Future?|author=[[Stephanie Cooke]] |date=October 10, 2011 |work=New York Times }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/15/columns-us-japan-nuclear-protest-idUSTRE75A0QH20110615 |title=Japan anti-nuclear protesters rally after quake |author=Antoni Slodkowski |date=June 15, 2011 |work=Reuters }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/14/world/asia/14japan.html?_r=1&hp |title=Japan Premier Wants Shift Away From Nuclear Power |author=Hiroko Tabuchi |date=July 13, 2011 |work=New York Times }}</ref> An energy white paper, approved by the Japanese Cabinet in October 2011, stated that "Public confidence in safety of nuclear power was greatly damaged" by the Fukushima nuclear disaster, and called for a reduction in the nation’s reliance on nuclear power.<ref name="Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada">{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-28/nuclear-promotion-dropped-in-japan-energy-policy-after-fukushima.html |title=Nuclear Promotion Dropped in Japan Energy Policy After Fukushima |author1=Tsuyoshi Inajima |author2=Yuji Okada |lastauthoramp=yes |date=Oct 28, 2011 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref>
Despite protests, on 1 July 2012 unit 3 of the [[Ōi Nuclear Power Plant]] was restarted.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Gerhardt|first=Tina|date=22 July 2012|title=After Fukushima, Nuclear Power on Collision Course with Japanese Public|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/156431/after_fukushima,_nuclear_power_on_collision_course_with_japanese_public|work=[[Alternet]]}}</ref> In September 2013, Ōi units 3 and 4 went offline, making Japan again completely without nuclear-produced electrical power.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201309150018 |title=Anti-nuke protesters call for end to nuclear energy use |publisher=The Asahi Shimbun |date=2013-09-13 |accessdate=2015-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129042212/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201309150018 |archivedate=2014-11-29 |df= }}</ref> On August 11, 2015, the [[Sendai Nuclear Power Plant]] was brought back online, followed by two units (3 and 4) of the [[Takahama Nuclear Power Plant]] on January 29, 2016.<ref name="pbs.org">https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/health-science-technology/nuclear-aftershocks/four-years-after-fukushima-japan-makes-a-return-to-nuclear-power/</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Japan restarts Takahama nuclear reactor ‹ Japan Today: Japan News and Discussion|url = http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/japan-restarts-takahama-nuclear-reactor|website = www.japantoday.com|access-date = 2016-02-01}}</ref> However, Unit 4 was shut down three days after restart due to an internal failure and Unit 3 in March 2016 after district court in Shiga prefecture issued an [[injunction]] to halt operation of Takahama Nuclear Power Plant.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-nuclear-courts-idUSKCN0WB0QH Japan court issues injunction to halt Takahama nuclear reactors]</ref><ref>[http://nuclearstreet.com/nuclear_power_industry_news/b/nuclear_power_news/archive/2016/03/09/kensai-power-to-take-takahama-unit-3-offline-030902 Kensai Electric Power To Take Takahama Unit 3 Offline]</ref> Though 43 of Japan's pre-2011 total of 54 plants remain idled, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in 2017 that if the country is to meet its obligations under the Paris climate accord, then nuclear energy needs to make up between 20-22% of the nation's portfolio mix. 26 restart applications are now pending with an estimated 12 units to come back in service by 2025 and 18 by 2030.<ref name=nei-20180704>{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/opinion/opinionjapan-is-there-a-future-in-nuclear-6231610/ |title=Japan - is there a future in nuclear? |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=4 July 2018 |accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Silverstein|first1=Ken|title=Japan Circling Back To Nuclear Power After Fukushima Disaster|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kensilverstein/2017/09/08/japan-may-be-coming-full-circle-after-its-fukushima-nuclear-energy-disaster/#7a7b6e4830e8|website=forbes.com|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Electricity production in Japan.PNG|thumb|right|Japan has steadily increased its nuclear generation over time. A dip in 2003 was due to TEPCO data falsification scandals in 2002 and caused a poor operating record.]] [[Image:Ikata Nuclear Powerplant.JPG|thumb|The [[Ikata Nuclear Power Plant]].]] [[Image:Kashiwazaki-Kariwa cropped.jpg|thumb|The [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]] as seen from space.]] [[Image:Tomari Nuclear Power Plant 01.jpg|thumb|The [[Tomari Nuclear Power Plant]].]]
===Early years=== ====Overcoming popular resistance==== In 1954, the [[Operations Coordinating Board]] of the [[United States National Security Council]] proposed that the U.S. government undertake a "vigorous offensive" urging nuclear energy for Japan in order to overcome the widespread reluctance of the Japanese population to build nuclear reactors in the country. Thirty two million Japanese people, a third of the Japanese population, signed a petition calling for banning [[hydrogen bomb]]s.<ref>John Swenson-Wright, "Unequal Allies: United States Security and Alliance Policy Toward Japan, 1945-1960 (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 2005), p. 181</ref> The [[Washington Post]] called for adopting the proposal to build nuclear reactors in Japan, stating: "Many Americans are now aware...that the dropping of the atomic bombs on Japan was not necessary....How better to make a contribution to amends than by offering Japan...atomic energy."<ref name=WaPo1954>Washington Post, 23 Sept. 1954, p. 18, "A Reactor for Japan"</ref> For several years starting in 1954, the [[United States Central Intelligence Agency]] and other U.S. government agencies ran a propaganda war targeting the Japanese population to vanquish the Japanese people's opposition to nuclear power.<ref>[[New York Times]], 8 June 1956, "Tokyo Press Stirs Ire of Americans"</ref><ref name=WaPo1954/>{{failed verification|date=November 2018}}
In 1954, Japan budgeted 230 million yen for nuclear energy, marking the beginning of the Japan's nuclear program. The [[Atomic Energy Basic Law]] limited activities to only peaceful purposes.<ref>Johnston, Eric, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110716f1.html Key players got nuclear ball rolling]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 16 July 2011, p. 3.</ref> The [[Tōkai Nuclear Power Plant|first nuclear reactor in Japan]] was built by the [[United Kingdom|UK]]'s [[General Electric Company plc|GEC]] and was commissioned in 1966.
====Light water reactors==== In the 1970s, the first [[light water reactor]]s were built in cooperation with American companies. These plants were bought from U.S. vendors such as [[General Electric]] and [[Westinghouse Electric Company|Westinghouse]] with contractual work done by Japanese companies, who would later get a license themselves to build similar plant designs. Developments in nuclear power since that time have seen contributions from Japanese companies and research institutes on the same level as the other big users of nuclear power. From the early 1970s to the present, the Japanese government promoted the siting of nuclear power plants through a variety of policy instruments involving soft social control and financial incentives.<ref>[[Daniel P. Aldrich]] 'How the Japanese Government Manipulated Public Opinion'[https://newrepublic.com/article/world/85463/japan-nuclear-power-regulation]</ref> By offering large subsidies and public works projects to rural communities and by using educational trips, junkets for local government officials, and OpEds written as news by pro-nuclear supporters, the central government won over the support of depopulating, hard-on-their-luck coastal towns and villages.
===Later years===
Japan's nuclear industry was not hit as hard by the effects of the [[Three Mile Island accident]] (TMI) or the [[Chernobyl disaster]] as some other countries. Construction of new plants continued to be strong through the 1980s, 1990s, and up to the present day. While many new plants had been proposed, all were subsequently canceled or never brought past initial planning. Cancelled plant orders include: * The [[Hōhoku Nuclear Power Plant]] at [[Hōhoku, Yamaguchi]]—1994 * The [[Kushima Nuclear Power Plant]] at [[Kushima, Miyazaki]]—1997 * The [[Ashihama Nuclear Power Plant]] at [[Ashihama, Mie]]—2000 (the first Project at the site in the 1970s was completed at Hamaoka as Unit 1&2) * The [[Maki Nuclear Power Plant]] at [[Maki, Niigata (Kambara)]]—Canceled in 2003 * The [[Suzu Nuclear Power Plant]] at [[Suzu, Ishikawa]]—2003
However, starting in the mid-1990s there were several nuclear related accidents and cover-ups in Japan that eroded public perception of the industry, resulting in protests and resistance to new plants. These accidents included the [[Tokaimura nuclear accident]], the [[Mihama Nuclear Power Plant|Mihama steam explosion]], cover-ups after an accident at the [[Monju Nuclear Power Plant|Monju reactor]], among others, more recently the [[2007 Chūetsu offshore earthquake|Chūetsu offshore earthquake]] aftermath. While exact details may be in dispute, it is clear that the safety culture in Japan's nuclear industry has come under greater scrutiny.<ref name="Japan cancels nuclear plant">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/652169.stm | work=BBC News | title=Japan cancels nuclear plant | date=February 22, 2000}} [The news fails to note that the Tokaimura accident did not happen in a power plant.]</ref>
===2000s===
On April 18, 2007, Japan and the United States signed the [[United States-Japan Joint Nuclear Energy Action Plan]], aimed at putting in place a framework for the joint research and development of nuclear energy technology.<ref>[https://www.energy.gov/news/4991.htm United States and Japan Sign Joint Nuclear Energy Action Plan] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720060428/http://www.energy.gov/news/4991.htm |date=2009-07-20 }}, ''[[United States Department of Energy]]'', published 2007-04-25, accessed 2007-05-02</ref> Each country will conduct research into [[fast reactor]] technology, fuel cycle technology, advanced computer simulation and modeling, small and medium reactors, safeguards and physical protection; and [[nuclear waste]] management.<ref>[https://www.energy.gov/media/USJapanFactSheet.pdf Fact Sheet: United States-Japan Joint Nuclear Energy Action Plan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521144837/http://www.energy.gov/media/USJapanFactSheet.pdf |date=2011-05-21 }}, ''[[United States Department of Energy]]'', published 2007-04-25, accessed 2007-05-02</ref> In March 2008, [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] announced that the start of operation of four new nuclear power reactors would be postponed by one year due to the incorporation of new earthquake resistance assessments. Units 7 and 8 of the Fukushima Daiichi plant would now enter commercial operation in October 2014 and October 2015, respectively. Unit 1 of the Higashidori plant is now scheduled to begin operating in December 2015, while unit 2 will start up in 2018 at the earliest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-New_Japanese_nuclear_power_reactors_delayed-260308.html |title=New Japanese nuclear power reactors delayed |publisher=World-nuclear-news.org |date=2008-03-26 |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> As of September 2008, Japanese ministries and agencies were seeking an increase in the 2009 budget by 6%. The total requested comes to 491.4 billion [[Japanese yen]] (4.6 billion USD), and the focuses of research are development of the fast breeder reactor cycle, next-generation light water reactors, the [[Iter]] project, and seismic safety.<ref>NucNet. [http://www.worldnuclear.org/_news_database/rss_detail_features.cfm?objID=82712AE9-DDAF-4807-94A71F1B04B33B71 Japan Budget Proposals Seek Increase In Nuclear Spending]. September 11, 2008.</ref>
===Fukushima disaster and aftermath=== {{main|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} {{expand section|date=May 2017}}
A 2011 independent investigation in Japan has "revealed a long history of nuclear power companies conspiring with governments to manipulate public opinion in favour of nuclear energy". One nuclear company "even stacked public meetings with its own employees who posed as ordinary citizens to speak in support of nuclear power plants".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-03/japan-nuclear-companies-stacked-public-meetings/3206288/?site=melbourne |title=Japan nuke companies stacked public meetings |author=Mark Willacy |date= October 3, 2011 |work=ABC News }}</ref> An energy white paper, approved by the Japanese Cabinet in October 2011, says "public confidence in safety of nuclear power was greatly damaged" by the Fukushima disaster, and calls for a reduction in the nation’s reliance on nuclear power. It also omits a section on nuclear power expansion that was in last year’s policy review.<ref name="Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada"/> Nuclear Safety Commission Chairman Haruki Madarame told a parliamentary inquiry in February 2012 that "Japan's atomic safety rules are inferior to global standards and left the country unprepared for the Fukushima nuclear disaster last March". There were flaws in, and lax enforcement of, the safety rules governing Japanese nuclear power companies, and this included insufficient protection against tsunamis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.businessweek.com/article.asp?documentKey=1376-LZF0E16JTSEY01-3P322MREJS02KO2666B7QSBOV9 |title=Nuclear Safety Chief Says Lax Rules Led to Fukushima Crisis |date=16 February 2012 |work=Bloomberg }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On 6 May 2011, Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] ordered the [[Hamaoka Nuclear Power Plant]] be shut down as an earthquake of magnitude 8.0 or higher is likely to hit the area within the next thirty years.<ref name="Story">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13306358 Story] at [[BBC]] News, 2011-05-06. retrieved 2011-05-08</ref><ref name="digitaljournal.com">[http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/306399 Story] at Digital Journal. retrieved 2011-05-07</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-07/chubu-electric-s-board-meets-on-possible-shutdown-of-nuclear-power-plant.html Story] at [https://www.bloomberg.com Bloomberg], 2011-05-07. retrieved 2011-05-08</ref><ref name="Japan nuke plant suspends work">{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/japan-nuke-plant-suspends-work/story-fn6s850w-1226056070930 |title=Japan nuke plant suspends work |date=May 15, 2011 |work=Herald Sun |page= }}</ref><ref name="M. V. Ramana 44">{{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/4/43.abstract |title=Nuclear power and the public |author=M. V. Ramana |date=July 2011 |volume=67 |issue=4 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |page=44 }}</ref>
As of 27 March 2012, Japan had only one out of 54 nuclear reactors operating; the [[Tomari Nuclear Power Plant#Reactors on site|Tomari-3]], after the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant#Reactors|Kashiwazaki-Kariwa 6]] was shut down.<ref name=ntse>[http://www.nyteknik.se/nyheter/energi_miljo/karnkraft/article3436603.ece "Soon Japan's nuclear power stands still"] ''[[NyTeknik]]'', 27 March 2012. Retrieved 27 March 2012. {{sv icon}} [http://translate.google.dk/translate?sl=sv&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=da&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nyteknik.se%2Fnyheter%2Fenergi_miljo%2Fkarnkraft%2Farticle3436603.ece English translation]</ref> The Tomari-3 was shut down for maintenance on 5 May, leaving Japan with no nuclear-derived electricity for the first time since 1970, when the country's then only two reactors was taken offline five days for maintenance.<ref name=Guardian/> On 15 June 2012, approval was given to restart [[Ōi Nuclear Power Plant|Ōi Units 3 and 4]]<ref>[http://www1.kepco.co.jp/gensi/monitor/live_unten/u_real.html Real-time display] Japanese - Ohi 3 and 4 are the last two on the page</ref> which could take six weeks to bring them to full operation. On 1 July 2012 unit 3 of the [[Ōi Nuclear Power Plant]] was restarted. This reactor can provide 1,180 [[Megawatts|MW]] of electricity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Davis |first=Will |url=http://atomicpowerreview.blogspot.com/2012/06/ohi-reactor-restart-in-japan-fully.html |title=Ohi reactor restart in Japan fully approved |publisher=Atomicpowerreview.blogspot.com |date=2012-06-15 |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2012/06/17/2003535527 |title=Japan approves two reactor restarts |publisher=Taipeitimes.com |date=2013-09-18 |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> On 21 July 2012 unit 4 was restarted, also 1,180 MW.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/oi-nuclear-plant-s-no-4-reactor-begins-generating-power_788863.html |title=Oi nuclear plant's No 4 reactor begins generating power |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> The reactor was shut down again on 14 September 2013, again leaving Japan with no operating power reactors.<ref>Matsuyama, Kanoko. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-16/shutdown-of-japan-s-last-nuclear-reactor-raises-power-concerns.html "Shutdown of Japan’s Last Nuclear Reactor Raises Power Concerns".] [https://www.bloomberg.com/ ''Bloomberg''.] 2013-09-15. Retrieved 2014-02-05.</ref>
Government figures in the 2014 Annual Report on Energy show that Japan depended on imported fossil fuels for 88% of its electricity in fiscal year 2013, compared with 62% in fiscal 2010. Without significant nuclear power, the country was self-sufficient for just 6% of its energy demand in 2012, compared with 20% in 2010. The additional fuel costs to compensate for its nuclear reactors being idled was ¥3.6 trillion. In parallel, domestic energy users have seen a 19.4% increase in their energy bills between 2010 and 2013, while industrial users have seen their costs rise 28.4% over the same period.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NP-Japan-continues-to-count-cost-of-idled-reactors-1706144.html/| title=Japan continues to count cost of idled reactors |publisher=[[World Nuclear News]] |date=June 17, 2014}}</ref>
In 2018 the Japanese government revised its energy plan to update the 2030 target for nuclear energy to 20%-22% of power generation by restarting reactors, compared to LNG 27%, coal 25%, renewables 23% and oil 3%. This would reduce Japan's carbon dioxide emissions by 26% compared to 2013, and increase self-sufficiency to about 24% by 2030, compared to 8% in 2016.<ref name=wnn-20180703>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NP-Japanese-Cabinet-approves-new-basic-energy-plan-0307184.html |title=Japanese Cabinet approves new basic energy plan |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=3 July 2018 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
====Investigations on the Fukushima disaster====
The [[National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission]] (NAIIC) is the first independent investigation commission by the [[Diet of Japan|National Diet]] in the 66-year history of Japan’s constitutional government. NAICC was established on December 8, 2011 with the mission to investigate the direct and indirect causes of the Fukushima nuclear accident. NAICC submitted its inquiry report to both houses on July 5, 2012.{{refn| group = lower-alpha |The [http://naiic.go.jp/en/ startpage of the Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission internetsite] stated on July 10, 2012 the following information which was used as the basis for the previous sentences: "NAIIC (The National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission) is the first independent investigation commission by the National Diet in the 66-year history of Japan’s constitutional government. NAICC was established on December 8, 2011 with the mission to investigate the direct and indirect causes of the Fukushima nuclear incident. NAICC submitted its inquiry report to both houses on July 5, 2012."}}<ref>{{cite web|title=国会事故調 {{!}} 東京電力福島原子力発電所事故調査委員会のホームページ|url=http://naiic.o.jp/en/|publisher=National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission|accessdate=9 July 2012|author=National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission}}</ref>
The 10-member commission compiled its report based on more than 1,167 interviews and 900 hours of hearings.<ref name="WP20120705W">{{cite news|last=Harlan|first=Chico|title=Report blasts Japan’s preparation for, response to Fukushima disaster|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/new-report-blasts-japans-preparation-for-response-to-fukushima-disaster/2012/07/05/gJQAN1OEPW_story.html|accessdate=9 July 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=5 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="NYT20120705">{{cite news|title=Inquiry Declares Fukushima Crisis a Man-Made Disaster|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/06/world/asia/fukushima-nuclear-crisis-a-man-made-disaster-report-says.html?_r=2|accessdate=9 July 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=5 July 2012|author=Hiroko Tabuchi}}</ref> It was a six-month independent investigation, the first of its kind with wide-ranging subpoena powers in Japan's constitutional history, which held public hearings with former Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] and [[Tokyo Electric Power Company|Tokyo Electric Power Co]]'s former president [[Masataka Shimizu]], who gave conflicting accounts of the disaster response.<ref name="Bloomberg20120705">{{cite web|title=Fukushima nuclear accident 'man-made', not natural disaster|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/fukushima-nuclear-accident--manmade-not-natural--disaster-20120705-21jrl.html|work=Bloomberg|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=9 July 2012}}</ref> The commission chairman, Kiyoshi Kurokawa, declared with respect to the Fukushima nuclear incident: “It was a profoundly man-made disaster — that could and should have been foreseen and prevented.”<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan’s nuclear meltdown could have been prevented|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/japans-nuclear-meltdown-could-have-been-prevented/2012/07/05/gJQAf9nPQW_story.html|accessdate=9 July 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=6 July 2012|author=Editorial Board}}</ref> He added that the "fundamental causes" of the disaster were rooted in "the ingrained conventions of Japanese culture."<ref>{{cite web|title=Message from the Chairman|url=http://naiic.go.jp/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/NAIIC_report_lo_res2.pdf|work=Executive Summary, The official report of The Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission|publisher=NAIIC|accessdate=12 July 2012|author=Kiyoshi Kurokawa|page=9|quote=What must be admitted – very painfully – is that this was a disaster "Made in Japan". Its fundamental causes are to be found in the ingrained conventions of Japanese culture: our reflexive obedience; our reluctance to question authority; our devotion to ‘sticking with the program’; our groupism; and our insularity.}}</ref> The report outlines errors and willful negligence at the plant before the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] on March 11, 2011 and a flawed response in the hours, days and weeks that followed. It also offers recommendations and encourages Japan's parliament to "thoroughly debate and deliberate" the suggestions.<ref name="CNN20120705">{{cite web|title=Japanese parliament report: Fukushima nuclear crisis was 'man-made'|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/05/world/asia/japan-fukushima-report/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=9 July 2012|author1=Yoko Wakatsuki |author2=Jethro Mullen |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref>
===Post-Fukushima nuclear policy=== {{Image frame |width=620 |content={{Graphical timeline of Japan's power nuclear reactors}} |align=right }} Japan's new energy plan, approved by the Liberal Democratic Party cabinet in April 2014, calls nuclear power "the country's most important power source".<ref>http://en.haberler.com/japan-reverses-its-withdrawal-from-nuclear-power-418262/</ref> Reversing a decision by the previous Democratic Party, the government will re-open nuclear plants, aiming for "a realistic and balanced energy structure". In May 2014 the Fukui District Court blocked the restart of the Oi reactors.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2014/05/23/commentary/reflect-on-fukui-nuclear-ruling/|title=Reflect on Fukui nuclear ruling|date=23 May 2014|work=The Japan Times}}</ref> In April 2015 courts blocked the restarting of two reactors at [[Takahama Nuclear Power Plant]] but permitted the restart of two reactors at [[Sendai Nuclear Power Plant]].<ref name=economist-20150425>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21649557-court-cases-frustrate-efforts-restart-japans-nuclear-plants-legal-fallout |title=Nuclear power in Japan - Legal fallout |newspaper=The Economist |date=25 April 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> The government hopes that nuclear power will produce 20% of Japan’s electricity by 2030.<ref name=economist-20150425/>
As of June 2015, approval was being sought from the new Nuclear Regulatory Agency for 24 units to restart, of the 54 pre-Fukushima units. The units also have to be approved by the local prefecture authorities before restarting.<ref name=nei-20150624>{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/opinion/opinionjapan-what-is-the-future-for-nuclear-power-4608426/ |title=Japan - what is the future for nuclear power? |author=Steve Kidd |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=24 June 2015 |accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref>
In July 2015 fuel loading was completed at the [[Sendai Nuclear Power Plant|Sendai-1]] nuclear plant, it restarted August 11, 2015 and was followed by unit 2 on November 1, 2015. Japan’s Nuclear Regulatory Authority approved the restart of [[Ikata Nuclear Power Plant|Ikata-3]] which took place on April 19, 2016, this reactor is the fifth to receive approval to restart.<ref>http://www.nei.org/News-Media/News/Japan-Nuclear-Update</ref> The [[Takahama Nuclear Power Plant]] unit 4 restarted in May 2017 and unit 3 in June 2017.
In November 2016 Japan signed a nuclear cooperation agreement [[Nuclear power in India|with India]]. Japanese nuclear plant builders saw this as potential lifeline given that domestic orders had ended following the Fukushima disaster, and India is proposing to build about 20 new reactors over the next decade. However, there is Japanese domestic opposition to the agreement, as India has not agreed to the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]].<ref name=jt-20161111>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/12/business/international/japan-india-nuclear-deal.html |title=Japan's Nuclear Industry Finds a Lifeline in India After Foundering Elsewhere |author=Jonathan Soble |newspaper=The Japan Times |date=11 November 2016 |accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref>
In 2014, following the failure of the prototype [[Monju Nuclear Power Plant|Monju]] [[sodium-cooled fast reactor]], Japan agreed to cooperate in developing the French [[ASTRID (reactor)|ASTRID]] demonstration sodium-cooled fast breeder reactor.<ref name=bl-20140505>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-05-05/japan-to-work-with-france-on-future-fast-breeder-atomic-reactor |title=Japan to Work With France on Future Fast-Breeder Atomic |author=Tara Patel, Gregory Viscusi |publisher=Bloomberg |date=5 May 2014 |accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=mainichi-20161022>{{cite news |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20161022/p2a/00m/0na/005000c |title=France wants Japan to share 570 billion yen ASTRID reactor development cost |newspaper=The Mainichi |date=22 October 2016 |accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref> As of 2016, France was seeking the full involvement of Japan in the ASTRID development.<ref name=mainichi-20161022/><ref name=asahi-20160922>{{cite news |url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201609220057.html |title=Ministries spar as Japan focuses on fast reactor project in France |newspaper=The Asahi Shimbun |date=22 September 2016 |accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref>
==Seismicity== Japan has had a long [[Seismicity in Japan|history of earthquakes and seismic activity]], and destructive [[earthquake]]s, often resulting in [[tsunami]]s, occur several times a century. Due to this, concern has been expressed about the particular risks of constructing and operating nuclear power plants in Japan. [[Amory Lovins]] has said: "An earthquake-and-tsunami zone crowded with 127 million people is an un-wise place for 54 reactors".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/amory-lovins/nuclear-power-fukushima-_b_837643.html |title=With Nuclear Power, "No Acts of God Can Be Permitted" |author=Amory Lovins |date=March 18, 2011 |work=Huffington Post }}</ref> To date, the most serious seismic-related accident has been the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].
Professor [[Katsuhiko Ishibashi]], one of the [[Seismology|seismologists]] who have taken an active interest in the topic, coined the term ''[[genpatsu-shinsai]]'' (原発震災), from the Japanese words for "nuclear power" and "quake disaster" to express the potential worst-case catastrophe that could ensue.<ref name=why-worry>Katsuhiko Ishibashi, [http://www.japanfocus.org/-Ishibashi-Katsuhiko/2495 "Why worry? Japan's nuclear plants at grave risk from quake damage"] ''The Asia-Pacific Journal: Japan Focus'' (August 11, 2007) Also published by the ''International Herald Tribune'' (August 11, 2007). Retrieved March 24, 2011</ref><ref>Michael Reilly, [https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19526144.500-insight-where-not-to-build-nuclear-power-stations.html "Insight: Where not to build nuclear power stations"] (preview only) ''[[New Scientist]]'' (July 28, 2007). Retrieved March 24, 2011 {{subscription required}}</ref> Dr [[Kiyoo Mogi]], former chair of the Japanese [[Coordinating Committee for Earthquake Prediction]],<ref name="nature-07-07-25">[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v448/n7152/ Quake shuts world's largest nuclear plant] Nature, vol 448, 392-393, {{doi|10.1038/448392a}}, published 2007-07-25, accessed 2011-03-18</ref> has expressed similar concerns, stating in 2004 that the issue 'is a critical problem which can bring a catastrophe to Japan through a man-made disaster'.<ref name=mogi-2004>[http://www.terrapub.co.jp/journals/EPS/pdf/2004/5608/5608li.pdf Two grave issues concerning the expected Tokai Earthquake] Kiyoo Mogi, ''Earth Planets Space'', Vol. 56 (No. 8), pp. li-lxvi, published 2004, accessed 2011-03-11</ref><ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/264/5166/1656.extract Japan Holds Firm to Shaky Science] ''Science'', Vol. 264 no. 5166 pp. 1656-1658, {{doi|10.1126/science.264.5166.1656}}, published 1994-06-17, accessed 2011-03-18</ref>
Warnings from Kunihiko Shimazaki, a professor of seismology at the University of Tokyo, were also ignored. In 2004, as a member of an influential cabinet office committee on offshore earthquakes, Mr. Shimazaki "warned that Fukushima's coast was vulnerable to tsunamis more than twice as tall as the forecasts of as much as five meters put forth by regulators and Tokyo Electric".<ref name=jap12/> Minutes of the meeting on Feb. 19, 2004, show that the government bureaucrats running the committee moved quickly to exclude his views from the committee's final report. He said the committee did not want to force Tokyo Electric to make expensive upgrades at the plant.<ref name=jap12>{{cite web |url=http://www.power-eng.com/news/2012/03/11/warnings-on-fukushima-ignored-insiders-say-nl-they-attribute-failure-to-cozy-ties-between-government.html |title=Warnings on Fukushima ignored, insiders say; They attribute failure to cozy ties between government and industry |date=03/11/2012 |work=Power Engineering }}</ref>
[[Hidekatsu Yoshii]], a member of the [[House of Representatives of Japan|House of Representatives]] for [[Japanese Communist Party]] and an [[Anti-nuclear movement|anti-nuclear campaigner]], warned in March and October 2006 about the possibility of the severe damage that might be caused by a tsunami or earthquake.<ref name=wsj-11-03-28>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703576204576226530875684182|title=Lawmaker Broached Plant Risk|author1=Dvorak, Phred |author2=Hayashi, Yuka |publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=March 28, 2011}}</ref> During a parliamentary committee in May 2010 he made similar claims, warning that the cooling systems of a Japanese nuclear plant could be destroyed by a landslide or earthquake.<ref name=wsj-11-03-28 /> In response [[Yoshinobu Terasaka]], head of the [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]], replied that the plants were so well designed that "such a situation is practically impossible".<ref name=wsj-11-03-28 /> Following damage at the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]] due to the [[2007 Chūetsu offshore earthquake]], Kiyoo Mogi called for the immediate closure of the [[Hamaoka Nuclear Power Plant]],<ref name="nature-07-07-25"/><ref name=times-07-07-19>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article2096238.ece Nuclear crisis in Japan as scientists reveal quake threat to power plants] The Times, published 2007-07-19, accessed 2011-03-18</ref> which was knowingly built close to the centre of the expected [[Tokai earthquakes|Tōkai earthquake]].<ref name=mogi-2004 /> Katsuhiko Ishibashi previously claimed, in 2004, that Hamaoka was "considered to be the most dangerous nuclear power plant in Japan".<ref name=japantimes-04-05-23>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20040523x2.html Japan's deadly game of nuclear roulette] The Japan Times, published 2004-05-23, accessed 2011-03-18</ref>
The [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) has also expressed concern. At a meeting of the [[G8|G8's]] Nuclear Safety and Security Group, held in Tokyo in 2008, an IAEA expert warned that a strong [[earthquake]] with a [[Richter magnitude scale#Richter magnitudes|magnitude]] above {{nowrap|7.0}} could pose a 'serious problem' for Japan's nuclear power stations.<ref name=wl>{{cite web|url=http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-03-iaea-japan-nuclear-quake-wikileaks.html |title=IAEA warned Japan over nuclear quake risk: WikiLeaks |publisher=physorg.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> Before Fukushima, "14 lawsuits charging that risks had been ignored or hidden were filed in Japan, revealing a disturbing pattern in which operators underestimated or hid seismic dangers to avoid costly upgrades and keep operating. But all the lawsuits were unsuccessful".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/6/44.full |title=Fukushima and the inevitability of accidents |author=Charles Perrow |date=November/December 2011 vol. 67 no. 6 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |pages= 44–52 }}</ref> Underscoring the risks facing Japan, a 2012 research institute investigation has "determined there is a 70% chance of a magnitude-7 earthquake striking the Tokyo metropolitan area within the next four years, and 98% over 30 years". The March 2011 earthquake was a magnitude-9.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204624204577178472176340772?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Japan Reviews Disaster Plan Amid New Quake Concerns |author=Mitsuru Obe |date=January 24, 2012 |work=Wall Street Journal }}</ref>
=== Design standards === [[Image:Japan Nuclear Earthquake Shaking.PNG|thumb|350px|Horizontal acceleration experienced and design values during the 2007 and 2011 major earthquake and earthquake-tsunami events.]] Between 2005 and 2007, three Japanese nuclear power plants were shaken by earthquakes that far exceeded the maximum [[peak ground acceleration]] used in their design.<ref name=autralian-11-03-13>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/japans-nuclear-plant-quake-protection-too-lax-said-expert/story-fn84naht-1226020553408 Japan's nuclear plant quake protection too lax, said expert] [[The Australian]] published 2011-03-13, accessed 2011-04-06</ref> The [[tsunami]] that followed the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku earthquake]], inundating the [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]], was more than twice the design height,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Fukushima_faced_14-metre_tsunami_2303113.html |title=Fukushima faced 14-metre tsunami |date=23 March 2011|publisher=World Nuclear News |accessdate=March 24, 2011}}</ref> while the ground acceleration also slightly exceeded the design parameters.<ref>[http://neutroneconomy.blogspot.com/2011/04/japans-earthquake-regulations.html Japan's Earthquake Regulations for Nuclear Power] ''The Neutron Economy'' published 2011-04-04, accessed 2011-04-06</ref>
In 2006 a Japanese government subcommittee<!-- probably the Subcommittee on Safety Examination Guidelines for Seismic Design--> was charged with revising the national guidelines on the earthquake-resistance of nuclear power plants, which had last been partially revised in 2001,<ref name=2006-seismic-guide>[http://www.nsc.go.jp/english/taishin.pdf Regulatory Guide for Reviewing Seismic Design of Nuclear Power Reactor Facilities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721224251/http://www.nsc.go.jp/english/taishin.pdf |date=2011-07-21 }} [[Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission|Nuclear Safety Commission]], published 2006-09-19, accessed 2011-04-06</ref> resulting in the publication of a new seismic guide — the 2006 ''Regulatory Guide for Reviewing Seismic Design of Nuclear Power Reactor Facilities''.<ref name=2006-seismic-guide /> The subcommittee membership included Professor Ishibashi, however his proposal that the standards for surveying active [[Fault (geology)|faults]] should be reviewed was rejected and he resigned at the final meeting, claiming that the review process was 'unscientific'<ref name="nature-07-07-25"/><ref name=businessweek-11-03-11>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-17/japan-nuclear-disaster-caps-decades-of-faked-reports-accidents.html |title=Japan Nuclear Disaster Caps Decades of Faked Reports, Accidents |author=Jason Clenfield |date=March 17, 2011 |work=Bloomberg Businessweek }}</ref> and the outcome rigged<ref name=businessweek-11-03-11 /><ref name=bloomberg-07-12-12>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=awR8KsLlAcSo Japan Nuclear Energy Drive Compromised by Conflicts of Interest] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]], published 2007-12-12, accessed 2011-04-11</ref> to suit the interests of the [[Japan Electric Association]], which had 11 of its committee members on the 19-member government subcommittee.<ref name=bloomberg-07-12-12 /> Ishibashi has subsequently claimed that, although the new guide brought in the most far-reaching changes since 1978, it was 'seriously flawed' because it underestimated the [[Peak ground acceleration|design basis earthquake ground motion]].<ref name=why-worry /> He has also claimed that the enforcement system is 'a shambles'<ref name=why-worry /><ref name=autralian-11-03-13 /> and questioned the independence of the [[Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission|Nuclear Safety Commission]] after a senior Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency official appeared to rule out a new review of the NSC's seismic design guide in 2007.<ref name=why-worry />
Following publication of the new 2006 Seismic Guide, the [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]], at the request of the Nuclear Safety Commission, required the design of all existing nuclear power plants to be re-evaluated.<ref>[http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news/20070730_nsc.pdf The NSC views on, and future actions to take for, the impacts due to the Niigata-ken Chuetsu-oki Earthquake in 2007 - NSC Decision No. 17, 2007] [[Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission|Nuclear Safety Commission]], published 2007-07-30, accessed 2011-04-06</ref>
=== Geological surveys === The standard of geological survey work in Japan is another area causing concern. In 2008 Taku Komatsubara, a [[Geology|geologist]] at the [[National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology]] alleged that the presence of active [[Fault (geology)|faults]] was deliberately ignored when surveys of potential new power plant sites were undertaken, a view supported by a former [[topography|topographer]].<ref>[http://www.upiasia.com/Security/2008/06/12/japans_nuclear_facilities_face_quake_risk/3945/ Japan's nuclear facilities face quake risk] UPI Asia, published 2008-06-12, accessed 2011-04-11</ref> Takashi Nakata, a seismologist from the [[Hiroshima Institute of Technology]] has made similar allegations, and suggest that conflicts of interest between the Japanese nuclear industry and the regulators contribute to the problem.<ref name=bloomberg-07-12-12 />
A 2011 [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] report that evaluated the seismic hazard to reactors worldwide, as determined by the Global Seismic Hazard Assessment Program data, placed 35 of Japan's reactors in the group of 48 reactors worldwide in very high and high seismic hazard areas.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://docs.nrdc.org/nuclear/files/nuc_11102801a.pdf |title=Global Implications of the Fukushima Disaster for Nuclear Power |author1=Thomas B. Cochran |author2=Matthew G. McKinzie |publisher=Natural Resources Defense Council |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=24 February 2012 |journal= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726084146/http://docs.nrdc.org/nuclear/files/nuc_11102801a.pdf |archive-date=2012-07-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Nuclear power plants == {{for|the details of each reactor|list of nuclear reactors#Japan}} As of May 2018, there are 39 operable reactors in Japan. Of these, 9 reactors in 5 power plants are currently operating.<ref name=WNNgenkai4 /> Additionally, 5 reactors have been approved for restart and further 12 have restart applications under review.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuclear Power Plants in Japan - The Federation of Electric Power Companies of Japan(FEPC)|url=http://www.fepc.or.jp/english/nuclear/power_generation/plants/index.html|website=www.fepc.or.jp|accessdate=1 May 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name=WNNgenkai4 />
